channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Are you a postdoc working in academia or industry? Share your career experiences with Nature
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01877-2

Our second global survey of postdoctoral researchers is now live, with new questions to reflect seismic changes to the world of work since 2020.
item.dc:title: Are you a postdoc working in academia or industry? Share your career experiences with Nature
item.dc:creator: David Payne

item.title: Why Nature will not allow the use of generative AI in images and video
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01546-4

Saying ‘no’ to this kind of visual content is a question of research integrity, consent, privacy and intellectual-property protection.
item.dc:title: Why Nature will not allow the use of generative AI in images and video

item.title: A metal-poor star with abundances from a pair-instability supernova
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06028-1

The chemical composition of the Galactic halo star J1010+2358 shows extremely low sodium and cobalt abundances, different from most other halo stars, indicative of a very metal-poor star being seeded with elements from a pair-instability supernova.
item.dc:title: A metal-poor star with abundances from a pair-instability supernova
item.dc:creator: Qian-Fan Xing
Gang Zhao
Zheng-Wei Liu
Alexander Heger

Wako Aoki
Yu-Qin Chen
Miho N. Ishigaki
Hai-Ning Li
Jing-Kun Zhao

item.title: China’s rolling COVID waves could hit every six months — infecting millions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01872-7

The latest surge is unlikely to crash the country’s health-care system, but scientists fear hundreds of millions of infections.
item.dc:title: China’s rolling COVID waves could hit every six months — infecting millions
item.dc:creator: Yvaine Ye

item.title: Deaths of African cheetahs in India shine spotlight on controversial conservation project
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 07 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01861-w

Scientists fear that an Indian park is not enough space for the planned population — and that not enough work has been done with locals on how they will respond to the animals.
item.dc:title: Deaths of African cheetahs in India shine spotlight on controversial conservation project
item.dc:creator: Gayathri Vaidyanathan

item.title: ChatGPT: standard reporting guidelines for responsible use
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01853-w

ChatGPT: standard reporting guidelines for responsible use
item.dc:title: ChatGPT: standard reporting guidelines for responsible use
item.dc:creator: Giovanni E. Cacciamani

Gary S. Collins

item.title: Iran: renovated irrigation network deepens water crisis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01851-y

Iran: renovated irrigation network deepens water crisis
item.dc:title: Iran: renovated irrigation network deepens water crisis
item.dc:creator: Mohsen Maghrebi

item.title: From the archive: ancient timelines and a west-side story of cities
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01814-3

Snippets from Nature’s past.
item.dc:title: From the archive: ancient timelines and a west-side story of cities

item.title: Preserve cultural diversity in author names
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01852-x

Preserve cultural diversity in author names
item.dc:title: Preserve cultural diversity in author names
item.dc:creator: Khaled Moustafa

item.title: The Arctic could go ice-free in less than a decade
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01857-6

Even stringent emission limits will not preserve the end-of-summer ice on Arctic seas.
item.dc:title: The Arctic could go ice-free in less than a decade

item.title: Lasers pierce the stunning dark skies of the Atacama Desert
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01876-3

One of the world’s most advanced telescopes, located in Chile, uses the beams to make artificial stars.
item.dc:title: Lasers pierce the stunning dark skies of the Atacama Desert

item.title: Tanzania’s researchers offered US$22,000 to publish in international journals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01729-z

The move is designed to encourage research and help boost institutions’ rankings. But some researchers say it will reward those already established in their careers.
item.dc:title: Tanzania’s researchers offered US$22,000 to publish in international journals
item.dc:creator: Syriacus Buguzi

item.title: Why we can thank a polio emergency for the birth of intensive care
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01830-3

An outbreak of polio in 1950s Denmark led one hospital to pioneer mechanical ventilation, constant monitoring of vital signs and other innovations that are saving lives to this day.
item.dc:title: Why we can thank a polio emergency for the birth of intensive care
item.dc:creator: Eric Topol

item.title: The inspiring story of the Tara and its 20-year message from the corals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01826-z

A remarkable research ship’s voyages to understand marine biodiversity show how visionary thinking can boost understanding of the natural world — and help to better preserve it.
item.dc:title: The inspiring story of the Tara and its 20-year message from the corals

item.title: Does shingles vaccination cut dementia risk? Large study hints at a link
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01824-1

Analysis of nearly 300,000 people finds an association between the shingles jab and a lower rate of dementia — but questions linger.
item.dc:title: Does shingles vaccination cut dementia risk? Large study hints at a link
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: ‘Science was heard’: woman who was convicted of killing her children pardoned after inquiry
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 06 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01871-8

Kathleen Folbigg, who was jailed in Australia in 2003 over the sudden deaths of her four young children, has been pardoned and released in the wake of new scientific evidence.
item.dc:title: ‘Science was heard’: woman who was convicted of killing her children pardoned after inquiry
item.dc:creator: Dyani Lewis

item.title: My mission to grow fruit without the plant
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01834-z

Lucas van der Zee hopes to restore current farmland to its natural state by eliminating the vegetation stage of crop-growing.
item.dc:title: My mission to grow fruit without the plant
item.dc:creator: James Mitchell Crow

item.title: New Zealand volcano: science agency pleads guilty to risk-assessment charge
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01777-5

The charge relates to how GNS Science communicated volcanic risk to contractors in the years before the Whakaari White Island eruption in 2019.
item.dc:title: New Zealand volcano: science agency pleads guilty to risk-assessment charge
item.dc:creator: Dyani Lewis

item.title: Spatial variations in aromatic hydrocarbon emission in a dust-rich galaxy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05998-6

We present James Webb Space Telescope observations that detect the 3.3 μm polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon feature in a galaxy observed less than 1.5 billion years after the Big Bang.
item.dc:title: Spatial variations in aromatic hydrocarbon emission in a dust-rich galaxy

item.title: When a loved one dies: how academia can support bereaved colleagues
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01832-1

Finding time and space to grieve for a partner, child or friend can be complicated for researchers — and the peers who support them.
item.dc:title: When a loved one dies: how academia can support bereaved colleagues
item.dc:creator: Jyoti Madhusoodanan

item.title: JWST spots the most distant ‘smoke’ molecules ever seen in space
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01844-x

The presence of the molecules in an early galaxy means it must have pumped out stars at a furious pace, researchers say.
item.dc:title: JWST spots the most distant ‘smoke’ molecules ever seen in space
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: Sleep loss impairs memory of smells, worm research shows
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01849-6

Sleeping C. elegans offers clues to the molecular changes underpinning the link between sleep and memory.
item.dc:title: Sleep loss impairs memory of smells, worm research shows
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.title: Scientific utopias: scientific enlightenment in the Stupid Questions Office
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01856-7

Earlier this year, Nature co-sponsored a science-fiction essay competition. According to runner-up Miles Lizak’s science-fiction essay, an ideal research institution would foster curiosity and collaboration, placing greater value on asking brave questions rather than claiming to know all the answers.
item.dc:title: Scientific utopias: scientific enlightenment in the Stupid Questions Office
item.dc:creator: Miles Lizak

item.title: Daily briefing: Europe ponders ‘no pay’ open-access publishing plan
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01875-4

The Council of the European Union has recommended an academic-publishing model in which neither readers nor authors pay. Plus, the astonishing microbial diversity among coral reefs and how to avoid the pitfalls of coding with ChatGPT.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: Europe ponders ‘no pay’ open-access publishing plan
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Golden jubilee for an iconic financial formula
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01811-6

Fifty years ago, an equation called the Black–Scholes formula revolutionized finance, leading to a rapid growth of markets and stimulating quantitatively oriented minds. But, with time, its simplicity became a liability — and yet its legacy persists.
item.dc:title: Golden jubilee for an iconic financial formula
item.dc:creator: Blanka N. Horvath

item.title: Six tips for better coding with ChatGPT
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01833-0

Although powerful, the tools are not as intelligent as they seem. Use them with caution, computer scientists warn.
item.dc:title: Six tips for better coding with ChatGPT
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey M. Perkel

item.title: Scientific utopias: the Eclosion Event
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01854-9

Earlier this year, Nature co-sponsored a science-fiction essay competition. Runner-up Evandro Ferrada’s science-fiction piece depicts science and a research culture transformed by limitless energy.
item.dc:title: Scientific utopias: the Eclosion Event
item.dc:creator: Evandro Ferrada

item.title: Frank Shu (1943–2023)
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01831-2

Astrophysicist who researched galactic structure and star formation.
item.dc:title: Frank Shu (1943–2023)
item.dc:creator: Douglas Lin
Fred Adams

item.title: Accidental DNA collection by air sensors could revolutionize wildlife tracking
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01850-z

Filters at air-pollution monitoring stations trap DNA from a multitude of flora and fauna, researchers find.
item.dc:title: Accidental DNA collection by air sensors could revolutionize wildlife tracking
item.dc:creator: Natasha Gilbert

item.title: Scientific utopias: tackling an early-morning crisis at the Institute of Merged Sciences
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01855-8

Earlier this year, Nature co-sponsored a science-fiction essay competition. In Katherine Ember’s winning essay, researchers have an immediate responsibility to the public. They’re asked to act urgently to help society.
item.dc:title: Scientific utopias: tackling an early-morning crisis at the Institute of Merged Sciences
item.dc:creator: Katherine Ember

item.title: The US Supreme Court has gutted federal protection for wetlands — now what?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 05 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01827-y

Most US wetlands just lost federal protection, but there’s still time for state and local governments to act. Scientists and the public can help.
item.dc:title: The US Supreme Court has gutted federal protection for wetlands — now what?
item.dc:creator: Royal C. Gardner

item.title: The mortality revolution, and the myth of the market: Books in brief
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01820-5

Andrew Robinson reviews five of the best science picks.
item.dc:title: The mortality revolution, and the myth of the market: Books in brief
item.dc:creator: Andrew Robinson

item.title: How to make the workplace fairer for female researchers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01829-w

Nature marked International Women’s Day by asking readers how to achieve gender equality in science.
item.dc:title: How to make the workplace fairer for female researchers
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson

item.title: EU council’s ‘no pay’ publishing model draws mixed response
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01810-7

Some academics have welcomed the proposed open-access plans. But publishing-industry representatives warn they are unrealistic and lack detail.
item.dc:title: EU council’s ‘no pay’ publishing model draws mixed response
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson

item.title: ‘It’s a vote for hope’: first gene therapy for muscular dystrophy nears approval, but will it work?
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01799-z

The FDA’s decision, expected this month, follows several setbacks and delays and will pose difficult choices for the families of children with Duchenne muscular dystrophy.
item.dc:title: ‘It’s a vote for hope’: first gene therapy for muscular dystrophy nears approval, but will it work?
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: Colombia’s ‘cocaine hippo’ population is even bigger than scientists thought
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01818-z

The most comprehensive census yet reveals that there could be twice as many of the invasive animals than previous estimates indicated.
item.dc:title: Colombia’s ‘cocaine hippo’ population is even bigger than scientists thought
item.dc:creator: Luke Taylor

item.title: The world’s first pollinating frog and more — May’s best science images
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01804-5

The month’s sharpest science shots, selected by Nature’s photo team.
item.dc:title: The world’s first pollinating frog and more — May’s best science images
item.dc:creator: Emma Stoye

item.title: Daily briefing: A light-activated process for cleaner chemicals
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01863-8

The genomes of the 233 primate species were used to classify 4.3 million common gene variants present in the human genome. Plus, a light-activated process for cleaner chemicals and how to launch a journal club for preprints.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: A light-activated process for cleaner chemicals
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Epic voyage finds astonishing microbial diversity among coral reefs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01807-2

World’s largest survey of Pacific corals clocked 100,000 kilometres, collecting 58,000 samples from 249 locations, including Indonesia, Japan and Papua New Guinea.
item.dc:title: Epic voyage finds astonishing microbial diversity among coral reefs
item.dc:creator: Natasha Gilbert

item.title: How to deliver a safer research culture for LGBTQIA+ researchers
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 02 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01400-7

Scientists from these communities mark the start of Pride Month by describing how colleagues and collaborators can better support them in lab and fieldwork settings.
item.dc:title: How to deliver a safer research culture for LGBTQIA+ researchers
item.dc:creator: Adam Levy

item.dc:title: Publisher Correction: Targeting PD-L2–RGMb overcomes microbiome-related immunotherapy resistance

First truly single aperiodic tile discovered that can cover an infinite surface without repeating itself.

item.title: A storm is whirling atop Uranus
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01767-7

Strongly flowing winds are detected inside a bright spot at the giant planet’s north pole.
item.dc:title: A storm is whirling atop Uranus

item.title: Arab world’s first asteroid hopper will visit seven space rocks
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01806-3

The UAE’s MBR Explorer aims to solve mystery of ultra-red celestial body in the asteroid belt beyond Mars.
item.dc:title: Arab world’s first asteroid hopper will visit seven space rocks
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.title: Biggest ever study of primate genomes has surprises for humanity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01776-6

Genomes of humans’ closest relatives provide insight for conservation, human disease and the origins of social structures.
item.dc:title: Biggest ever study of primate genomes has surprises for humanity
item.dc:creator: Dyani Lewis

item.title: Preprint clubs: why it takes a village to do peer review
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01819-y

A group of early-career researchers have harnessed cross-institutional journal clubs to assess and review immunology preprints.
item.dc:title: Preprint clubs: why it takes a village to do peer review
item.dc:creator: Felix Clemens Richter
Ester Gea-Mallorquí

item.title: Daily briefing: We are exceeding the limits of Earth’s ability to support us
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01821-4

Humanity has crossed eight of nine ‘Earth-system boundaries’ for a healthy and fair world. Plus, the brain’s wrinkles help to drive how it works and an infinite tiling pattern that could end a 60-year mathematical quest.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: We are exceeding the limits of Earth’s ability to support us
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Thousands of early-career NIH researchers forming union for first time
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01845-w

Push for better pay and benefits among US scientists arrives at world’s largest biomedical funder.
item.dc:title: Thousands of early-career NIH researchers forming union for first time
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: Global plan for dealing with next pandemic just got weaker, critics say
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 01 June 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01805-4

Watered-down language in the latest draft of the ‘pandemic treaty’ worries researchers.
item.dc:title: Global plan for dealing with next pandemic just got weaker, critics say
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: These hardy ants build their own landmarks in the desert
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01766-8

Ants living on the sprawling salt pans of Tunisia use DIY markers to find their way home.
item.dc:title: These hardy ants build their own landmarks in the desert

item.title: AI identifies gene interactions to speed up search for treatment targets
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-01803-6

How an AI overcomes data-scarcity to map gene networks, and assessing the impact of rocket noise on wildlife.
item.dc:title: AI identifies gene interactions to speed up search for treatment targets
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe
Benjamin Thompson

item.title: Transannular C–H functionalization of cycloalkane carboxylic acids
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06000-z

Quinuclidine-pyridone and sulfonamide-pyridone ligands enable transannular γ-methylene C–H arylation of cycloalkane carboxylic acids with a range of ring sizes, bringing us closer to molecular editing of saturated carbocycles.
item.dc:title: Transannular C–H functionalization of cycloalkane carboxylic acids
item.dc:creator: Guowei Kang
Daniel A. Strassfeld
Tao Sheng
Chia-Yu Chen
Jin-Quan Yu

item.title: Deterministic evolution and stringent selection during preneoplasia
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06102-8

We model occult preneoplasia by biallelic inactivation of TP53, a common early event in gastric cancer, in human gastric organoids, the results implying predictability in the earliest stages of tumorigenesis.
item.dc:title: Deterministic evolution and stringent selection during preneoplasia
item.dc:creator: Kasper Karlsson
Moritz J. Przybilla
Eran Kotler
Aziz Khan
Hang Xu
Kremena Karagyozova

Christina Curtis

item.title: Axonemal structures reveal mechanoregulatory and disease mechanisms
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06140-2

Detailed atomic models of axonemes from algal flagella and human respiratory cilia, which are hair-like protrusions from cells that enable motility and clear mucus from human airways, could provide insights into how they function.
item.dc:title: Axonemal structures reveal mechanoregulatory and disease mechanisms
item.dc:creator: Travis Walton
Miao Gui
Simona Velkova
Mahmoud R. Fassad
Robert A. Hirst
Eric Haarman
Christopher O’Callaghan
Mathieu Bottier
Thomas Burgoyne
Hannah M. Mitchison
Alan Brown

item.title: Attosecond electron microscopy of sub-cycle optical dynamics
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06074-9

The cycles of laser light have been used to advance transmission electron microscopy to attosecond time resolution, revealing the interactions between light and matter in terms of their fundamental dimensions in space and time.
item.dc:title: Attosecond electron microscopy of sub-cycle optical dynamics
item.dc:creator: David Nabben
Joel Kuttruff
Levin Stolz
Andrey Ryabov
Peter Baum

item.title: Expertise increases planning depth in human gameplay
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06124-2

A computational model based on a heuristic value function and forward search algorithm predicts human choices, response times and eye movements in games of games of four-in-a-row, and shows evidence for increased planning and improved attention with increased expertise.
item.dc:title: Expertise increases planning depth in human gameplay
item.dc:creator: Bas van Opheusden
Ionatan Kuperwajs
Gianni Galbiati
Zahy Bnaya
Yunqi Li
Wei Ji Ma

item.title: Uncovering the Ediacaran phosphorus cycle
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06077-6

Reconstruction of oceanic phosphorus concentrations during a large negative carbon-isotope excursion co-occurring with global oceanic oxygenation and evolution of some of Earth’s earliest animals suggests that decoupled phosphorus and ocean anoxia cycles during the Ediacaran may have prolonged the rise of atmospheric oxygen.
item.dc:title: Uncovering the Ediacaran phosphorus cycle
item.dc:creator: Matthew S. Dodd
Wei Shi
Chao Li
Zihu Zhang
Meng Cheng
Haodong Gu
Dalton S. Hardisty

Timothy W. Lyons

item.title: A pan-influenza antibody inhibiting neuraminidase via receptor mimicry
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06136-y

The neuraminidase-targeting monoclonal antibody FNI9 potently inhibits the enzymatic activity of influenza A and B viruses via receptor mimicry.
item.dc:title: A pan-influenza antibody inhibiting neuraminidase via receptor mimicry
item.dc:creator: Corey Momont

item.title: Increasingly negative tropical water–interannual CO<sub>2</sub> growth rate coupling
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06056-x

Records show that tropical water availability rather than temperature appears to have been increasingly controlling the interannual variability of the terrestrial carbon cycle over the past 59 years.
item.dc:title: Increasingly negative tropical water–interannual CO<sub>2</sub> growth rate coupling
item.dc:creator: Laibao Liu
Philippe Ciais
Mengxi Wu
Ryan S. Padrón
Pierre Friedlingstein
Jonas Schwaab
Lukas Gudmundsson
Sonia I. Seneviratne

item.title: Characterization of just one atom using synchrotron X-rays
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06011-w

Using a specialized tip as a detector, the fingerprints of a single atom of iron and terbium are observed in synchrotron X-ray absorption spectra, allowing elemental and chemical characterization one atom at a time.
item.dc:title: Characterization of just one atom using synchrotron X-rays
item.dc:creator: Tolulope M. Ajayi
Nozomi Shirato

item.title: Enhanced rare-earth separation with a metal-sensitive lanmodulin dimer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05945-5

A study biochemically and structurally characterizes a lanmodulin from Hansschlegelia quercus with an oligomeric state sensitive to rare-earth ionic radius.
item.dc:title: Enhanced rare-earth separation with a metal-sensitive lanmodulin dimer
item.dc:creator: Joseph A. Mattocks
Jonathan J. Jung
Chi-Yun Lin
Ziye Dong
Neela H. Yennawar

Christina S. Kang-Yun
Timothy A. Hamilton
Dan M. Park
Amie K. Boal
Joseph A. Cotruvo Jr

item.title: Transfer learning enables predictions in network biology
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06139-9

A context-aware, attention-based deep learning model pretrained on single-cell transcriptomes enables predictions in settings with limited data in network biology and could accelerate discovery of key network regulators and candidate therapeutic targets.
item.dc:title: Transfer learning enables predictions in network biology
item.dc:creator: Christina V. Theodoris
Ling Xiao
Anant Chopra
Mark D. Chaffin
Zeina R. Al Sayed
Matthew C. Hill
Helene Mantineo
Elizabeth M. Brydon
Zexian Zeng
X. Shirley Liu
Patrick T. Ellinor

item.title: Strong and ductile titanium–oxygen–iron alloys by additive manufacturing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-05952-6

Combining alloy design with additive manufacturing process design creates α–β titanium–oxygen–iron alloys that are both strong and ductile, with the potential to revitalize off-grade sponge titanium and thereby reduce the carbon footprint of the titanium industry.
item.dc:title: Strong and ductile titanium–oxygen–iron alloys by additive manufacturing
item.dc:creator: Tingting Song
Zibin Chen
Xiangyuan Cui
Shenglu Lu
Hansheng Chen
Hao Wang

Simon P. Ringer
Ma Qian

item.title: In situ tumour arrays reveal early environmental control of cancer immunity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06132-2

Skin tumour array by microporation (STAMP) captures the dynamic relationships of spatial, cellular and molecular components of tumour rejection and has the potential to translate therapeutic concepts into successful clinical strategies.
item.dc:title: In situ tumour arrays reveal early environmental control of cancer immunity
item.dc:creator: Guadalupe Ortiz-Muñoz

item.title: Myelin dysfunction drives amyloid-β deposition in models of Alzheimer’s disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06120-6

Mouse models show that myelin dysfunction and associated inflammation increase with age, which can promote amyloid-β deposition and therefore risk of developing Alzheimer’s disease.
item.dc:title: Myelin dysfunction drives amyloid-β deposition in models of Alzheimer’s disease

item.title: The effects of cash transfers on adult and child mortality in low- and middle-income countries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06116-2

A survey of mortality data from low- and middle-income countries shows that government-led cash transfer programmes are associated with decreased mortality among women and children under five years of age.
item.dc:title: The effects of cash transfers on adult and child mortality in low- and middle-income countries
item.dc:creator: Aaron Richterman
Christophe Millien
Elizabeth F. Bair
Gregory Jerome
Jean Christophe Dimitri Suffrin
Jere R. Behrman
Harsha Thirumurthy

item.title: Pan-KRAS inhibitor disables oncogenic signalling and tumour growth
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06123-3

A non-covalent inhibitor that binds preferentially to the inactive state of KRAS while sparing NRAS and HRAS is reported, indicating that most KRAS oncoproteins cycle between an active state and an inactive state in cancer cells.
item.dc:title: Pan-KRAS inhibitor disables oncogenic signalling and tumour growth

item.title: Indefinite and bidirectional near-infrared nanocrystal photoswitching
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06076-7

This study reports unlimited near-infrared photoswitching in inorganic avalanching nanoparticles via a discrete shift of threshold intensity mediated by internal defect-based colour centres.
item.dc:title: Indefinite and bidirectional near-infrared nanocrystal photoswitching

item.title: Nuclear export of pre-60S particles through the nuclear pore complex
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 31 May 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06128-y

We report the cryo-electron microscopy structure of native pre-60S particles trapped in the channel of the yeast nuclear pore complex, suggesting a translocation model for the export of pre-60S particles through the complex.
item.dc:title: Nuclear export of pre-60S particles through the nuclear pore complex
